Award.AwardTitle: Genomic Structure and Contemporary Evolution of Weediness in Red Rice
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Ana L. Caicedo (University of Massachusetts Amherst)

CoPIs: Kenneth M. Olsen (Washington University) and Yulin Jia (University of Arkansas/USDA-ARS Dale Bumpers National Rice Research Center)

Key Collaborators: David Gealy (University of Arkansas/USDA-ARS Dale Bumpers National Rice Research Center) and Nilda Burgos (University of Arkansas)

Red rice is an aggressive, weedy form of cultivated rice that infests crop fields and is a primary factor limiting rice productivity in the U.S. and worldwide. As the weedy relative of a genomic model species, red rice is supremely suited to serve as a model for understanding the processes by which weediness emerges in agricultural settings. Previous work by this research group has revealed that red rice in the U.S. has arisen twice independently, in both cases from Asian domesticated rice. This project will further examine several complementary aspects of red rice evolution in three broad aims. First, leveraging current information about U.S. red rice origins, the project will examine the genetic basis by which weedy traits emerge. Candidate weedy genomic regions will be identified through comparison of whole-genome sequences of U.S. weedy rice strains with their putative cultivated ancestors, and through genetic analyses of weed-crop crosses. Second, the project will determine how the weed's origin and population structure compare among four world regions (South Asia, Southeast Asia, Northeast Asia, North America) that differ in the presence/absence of reproductively compatible wild species and in the predominant locally cultivated rice variety. Third, the project will assess how recent shifts in U.S. agriculture towards the use of imidazolinone (IMI) herbicide-resistant rice varieties are affecting the emergence of herbicide-resistant red rice. Specifically, the project will determine the relative roles of crop-weed gene flow versus spontaneous mutation in the creation of IMI-resistant weedy rice.

Weedy crop relatives are a leading cause of crop losses worldwide, and this research will provide the first detailed examination of the genetic mechanisms and demographic processes by which weediness can evolve. The work will also provide basic insights into the impact of recent shifts to herbicide resistant rice farming on weed evolution, thereby providing critical data for devising effective weed control strategies. Other broader impacts of the project will involve training of a teacher summer intern through collaboration with the nationally recognized Washington University Science Outreach (WUSO); the teacher intern will create a "red rice" lab activity for classroom use, which will be made available on the web, publicized through science outreach programs, and supported locally through the WUSO materials warehouse. Teacher mentoring will also take the form of biotechnology research training to science faculty at the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff, a historically African-American institution. The project will also participate in the annual Rice Research and Extension Center Field Day held in Stuttgart (AR). This popular event attracts a diverse cross-section of the public that include families, stake holders, state and regional rice research and extension specialists, industry representatives, congressional aides, and international visitors, providing an excellent opportunity to disseminate information about the the project and its relevance to rice agriculture. All sequence data generated will be available through through a project website (to be established) and long-term at public repositories that include GenBank and Gramene.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to understand the genetic and evolutionary mechanisms by which weedy rice, one of the worst weeds of cultivated rice, has continuously threatened rice cultivation worldwide. To do this, we harnessed the power of high throughput genotyping, and extensive phenotyping of weedy rice collected from the United States and various other parts of the world. Determining how weedy rice can arise and evolve its competitive abilities is a critical first step for devising effective weed control strategies that can benefit rice production worldwide.

Key findings for this project include:

1)    Two groups of weedy rice in the U.S. have evolved independently directly from separate cultivated rice varieties, though in both cases these are exotic cultivars rather than those cultivated in the U.S. One group evolved early in the domestication process and one late, demonstrating that de-domestication is a common source of this agricultural weed.

2)    Though currently occupying the same cultivated fields, weedy rice groups in the U.S. have used different genetic mechanism to evolve weedy traits. Moreover, it seems that very few genes have been selected on to complete the transition from domesticated crop to agricultural weed, indicating that this is a transition that can occur easily..

3)    Weedy rice groups in three different geographic regions of Asia (South, Southeast, and Northeast) and in Colombia have also evolved through de-domestication from crop ancestors. However, the cultivated varieties giving rise to weedy rice differ between regions.

4)    In at least two regions examined, South Asia and Southeast Asia, wild rice (i.e. the wild ancestor of cultivated rice) is native, and has also contributed to weedy rice evolution.

5)    The plethora of origins for weedy rice reveal that this is a case of extreme recurrent evolution, which makes control of this weed at a worldwide scale difficult. Moreover, this implies that wild and cultivated rice contain sufficient genetic variation to repeatedly give rise to weeds.

6)    Weedy rice in the U.S. carries broad resistance to two problematic diseases of cultivated rice: blast and sheath blight. Mining the genetic variation present in these weeds is helping identify resistance loci that can be used for rice crop improvement.

7)    As use of herbicide resistant rice cultivars has increased in the U.S., resistance to herbicide is also becoming common in weedy rice. 80% of fields surveyed with a history of herbicide resistant varieties had herbicide resistant weedy rice.

8)    Genetic data shows that weedy rice has been acquiring the herbicide resistance trait by crossing with cultivated resistant varieties, even though historically crossing between the crop and weeds has not been common.

9)    Herbicide resistant weedy rice has also inherited some less favorable traits from crops, such as loss of seed dormancy and reduced seed dispersal. Thus assiduous weed management may be successful at eliminating these types of weedy rice.

Our project has provided training and opportunities for research experience in the fields of evolutionary genomics and weed science to five postdoctoral researchers, nine graduate students, and at least 14 undergraduates. Moreover, it resulted in the development of curricula and lab activities for high school students, and familiarization of academic research to hard of hearing middle schoolers. Our project also shows how application of a genetic and evolutionary framework to weed research can provide important insight into history and practices that promote weed persistence and proliferation. Because agricultural weeds are one of the largest constraints on crop productivity, mining weed genomes for potential sources of crop improvement or for insight into effective control practices will become increasingly important to safeguard the world food supply.
